title: 1956 U.S. Open (golf)
text:
The 1956 U.S. Open was the 56th <a href="U.S.%20Open%20%28golf%29">U.S. Open</a>, held June 14–16 at the East Course of <a href="Oak%20Hill%20Country%20Club">Oak Hill Country Club</a> near <a href="Rochester%2C%20New%20York">Rochester, New York</a>. <a href="Cary%20Middlecoff">Cary Middlecoff</a> won his second U.S. Open title, one stroke ahead of runners-up <a href="Julius%20Boros">Julius Boros</a> and <a href="Ben%20Hogan">Ben Hogan</a>, both former champions.
Middlecoff began the final round with a two-stroke lead over Hogan, <a href="Ted%20Kroll">Ted Kroll</a>, and <a href="Wes%20Ellis">Wes Ellis</a>. After an erratic finish where he bogeyed 16 and 17, he carded a third consecutive round of even-par 70 to post a 281 (+1) total and waited. Hogan, pursuing his record fifth U.S. Open, had a chance to tie Middlecoff but missed a par putt on the 17th to finish one back. Boros also had a chance to catch Middlecoff, but missed a birdie on the last and also finished a stroke behind. The last contender on the course, Kroll led by a stroke after a birdie at the 14th hole, but immediately followed it with a bogey and triple bogey and finished four strokes back.
Reigning <a href="The%20Open%20Championship">British Open</a> champion <a href="Peter%20Thomson%20%28golfer%29">Peter Thomson</a> made a rare appearance in the United States and finished tied for fourth, his best finish at any other <a href="Men%27s%20major%20golf%20championships">major</a>. He was the 36-hole leader by a stroke over Hogan, but fell back after a four-over 39 on the back nine in the third round. Thomson won five British Opens, and his third consecutive (<a href="1954%20Open%20Championship">1954</a>–<a href="1956%20Open%20Championship">56</a>) came three weeks later at <a href="Royal%20Liverpool%20Golf%20Club%2C%20Hoylake">Royal Liverpool</a>. 
Several future champions made their mark at this U.S. Open. <a href="Arnold%20Palmer">Arnold Palmer</a>, 26, recorded the first of his thirteen top ten finishes at the U.S. Open, six strokes back in seventh place. <a href="Ken%20Venturi">Ken Venturi</a> captured low-<a href="Amateur%20sports%23Golf">amateur</a> honors in eighth place, two months after he lost a four-stroke lead at <a href="1956%20Masters%20Tournament">The Masters</a> with an 80 in the final round. <a href="Billy%20Casper">Billy Casper</a>, 24, made his major championship debut and finished 14th. 
Defending champion <a href="Jack%20Fleck">Jack Fleck</a>, who upset Hogan in a Sunday playoff the <a href="1955%20U.S.%20Open%20%28golf%29">year before</a> at <a href="Olympic%20Club">Olympic</a>, shot 76-74 and missed the cut by a stroke. <a href="Jack%20Burke%20Jr.">Jack Burke Jr.</a>, winner of the <a href="1956%20Masters%20Tournament">Masters</a> two months earlier, also missed with a 152.
A record-setting 13,914 were in attendance for the final two rounds on Saturday.
This was the first of three U.S. Opens at the East Course at Oak Hill; <a href="Lee%20Trevino">Lee Trevino</a> won in <a href="1968%20U.S.%20Open%20%28golf%29">1968</a> and <a href="Curtis%20Strange">Curtis Strange</a> successfully defended in <a href="1989%20U.S.%20Open%20%28golf%29">1989</a>. It also hosted the <a href="PGA%20Championship">PGA Championship</a> in <a href="1980%20PGA%20Championship">1980</a>, <a href="2003%20PGA%20Championship">2003</a>, and <a href="2013%20PGA%20Championship">2013</a>, and the <a href="Ryder%20Cup">Ryder Cup</a> in <a href="1995%20Ryder%20Cup">1995</a>.

"Thursday, June 14, 1956"
